questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic sign of cerebellar dysfunction?
A patient with a cerebellar lesion attempts to touch their nose with their finger. They overshoot the target and then oscillate back and forth. This finding is known as:
Dysdiadochokinesia, often seen in cerebellar disease, refers to the inability to perform:
Damage to the cerebellum can lead to ataxia, which is best described as:
options: Incoordination due to errors in the rate, range, force, and direction of movement
questions.answer: Incoordination due to errors in the rate, range, force, and direction of movement

questions.question: A patient with cerebellar dysfunction may exhibit a gait that is described as:
The cerebellum plays a crucial role in motor control. Which of the following is a key function attributed to the cerebellum?
options: Coordination of the force and extent of contraction of different muscles
questions.answer: Coordination of the force and extent of contraction of different muscles

questions.question: In cerebellar disease, voluntary movements may be characterized by:
options: A delay in initiation and decomposition of movement
questions.answer: A delay in initiation and decomposition of movement

questions.question: Which of the following reflexes may be altered in cerebellar dysfunction, resulting in a pendular quality?
options: Deep tendon reflexes may continue for a longer duration
questions.answer: Deep tendon reflexes may continue for a longer duration
